content.canonical: Background subagents do NOT inherit parent permissions - they require pre-approved permissions via ~/.claude/settings.json. Add "Write:*", "Edit:*", "Task:*" to permissions.allow array. This enables parallel worktree development with background agents.
content.expanded:
When working on this type of task, avoid: Assumed subagents inherit parent agent permissions automatically. When background subagents failed with "Permission auto-denied (prompts unavailable)", investigated complex solutions like passing allowedPrompts to Task tool.

Instead: Background subagents do NOT inherit parent permissions - they require pre-approved permissions via ~/.claude/settings.json. Add "Write:*", "Edit:*", "Task:*" to permissions.allow array. This enables parallel worktree development with background agents.

structured.avoid: Assumed subagents inherit parent agent permissions automatically. When background subagents failed with "Permission auto-denied (prompts unavailable)", investigated complex solutions like passing allowedPrompts to Task tool.
structured.prefer: Background subagents do NOT inherit parent permissions - they require pre-approved permissions via ~/.claude/settings.json. Add "Write:*", "Edit:*", "Task:*" to permissions.allow array. This enables parallel worktree development with background agents.

content.canonical: Beads export state auto-updates with each commit hash. After final push, restore the export state file instead of committing it again to break the cycle.
content.expanded:
When working on this type of task, avoid: Committed beads export state changes in a loop, causing infinite commits

Instead: Beads export state auto-updates with each commit hash. After final push, restore the export state file instead of committing it again to break the cycle.

structured.avoid: Committed beads export state changes in a loop, causing infinite commits
structured.prefer: Beads export state auto-updates with each commit hash. After final push, restore the export state file instead of committing it again to break the cycle.

content.canonical: When using subagents with git worktrees, either: (1) create worktrees inside the repo (e.g., .worktrees/feature-name) so subagents can access them, or (2) have the orchestrating agent do parallel work directly in main and manage branches/commits itself, then cherry-pick to a single consolidated branch.
content.expanded:
When working on this type of task, avoid: Created git worktrees as sibling directories (../floop-*) and spawned subagents to work in them. Subagents couldn't access worktree paths due to sandbox restrictions that block access outside the main repo directory.

Instead: When using subagents with git worktrees, either: (1) create worktrees inside the repo (e.g., .worktrees/feature-name) so subagents can access them, or (2) have the orchestrating agent do parallel work directly in main and manage branches/commits itself, then cherry-pick to a single consolidated branch.

structured.avoid: Created git worktrees as sibling directories (../floop-*) and spawned subagents to work in them. Subagents couldn't access worktree paths due to sandbox restrictions that block access outside the main repo directory.
structured.prefer: When using subagents with git worktrees, either: (1) create worktrees inside the repo (e.g., .worktrees/feature-name) so subagents can access them, or (2) have the orchestrating agent do parallel work directly in main and manage branches/commits itself, then cherry-pick to a single consolidated branch.

content.canonical: When subagents fail with "Permission auto-denied (prompts unavailable)", the issue is that background agents cannot request interactive permissions. The fix is to ensure subagents are granted necessary permissions upfront when spawned, OR to run them in foreground mode where they can request permissions. Investigate how to pass allowedPrompts or similar when spawning Task agents.
content.expanded:
When working on this type of task, avoid: Logged a learning that says orchestrating agent should do all writes when subagents fail due to permissions - this defeats the purpose of parallel subagent work

Instead: When subagents fail with "Permission auto-denied (prompts unavailable)", the issue is that background agents cannot request interactive permissions. The fix is to ensure subagents are granted necessary permissions upfront when spawned, OR to run them in foreground mode where they can request permissions. Investigate how to pass allowedPrompts or similar when spawning Task agents.

structured.avoid: Logged a learning that says orchestrating agent should do all writes when subagents fail due to permissions - this defeats the purpose of parallel subagent work
structured.prefer: When subagents fail with "Permission auto-denied (prompts unavailable)", the issue is that background agents cannot request interactive permissions. The fix is to ensure subagents are granted necessary permissions upfront when spawned, OR to run them in foreground mode where they can request permissions. Investigate how to pass allowedPrompts or similar when spawning Task agents.

content.canonical: Use git worktrees to give each parallel agent an isolated checkout on its own branch, then merge via PRs or cherry-picks
content.expanded:
When working on this type of task, avoid: Spawned parallel sub-agents working directly in the same worktree, risking file conflicts and uncommitted change contamination

Instead: Use git worktrees to give each parallel agent an isolated checkout on its own branch, then merge via PRs or cherry-picks

structured.avoid: Spawned parallel sub-agents working directly in the same worktree, risking file conflicts and uncommitted change contamination
structured.prefer: Use git worktrees to give each parallel agent an isolated checkout on its own branch, then merge via PRs or cherry-picks

content.canonical: When fixing bugs: (1) identify the bug, (2) write a test that fails due to that bug, (3) implement the fix, (4) verify the test passes. This builds confidence in the test suite as it expands.
content.expanded:
When working on this type of task, avoid: Identified a bug, then immediately implemented the fix without writing a failing test first

Instead: When fixing bugs: (1) identify the bug, (2) write a test that fails due to that bug, (3) implement the fix, (4) verify the test passes. This builds confidence in the test suite as it expands.

structured.avoid: Identified a bug, then immediately implemented the fix without writing a failing test first
structured.prefer: When fixing bugs: (1) identify the bug, (2) write a test that fails due to that bug, (3) implement the fix, (4) verify the test passes. This builds confidence in the test suite as it expands.

content.canonical: Plan with one agent, create beads, then hand off to fresh agent for implementation - keeps context clean and allows specialization
content.expanded:
When working on this type of task, avoid: Assumed same agent should continue from planning through implementation

Instead: Plan with one agent, create beads, then hand off to fresh agent for implementation - keeps context clean and allows specialization

structured.avoid: Assumed same agent should continue from planning through implementation
structured.prefer: Plan with one agent, create beads, then hand off to fresh agent for implementation - keeps context clean and allows specialization

content.canonical: When using subagents for parallel work: (1) Have subagents do read-only tasks (research, exploration, planning), (2) Have the orchestrating agent do all file writes based on subagent findings, OR (3) Use worktrees but do the actual implementation work yourself after subagents gather context
content.expanded:
When working on this type of task, avoid: Spawned background subagents to write code in worktrees, but they failed with "Permission to use Write has been auto-denied (prompts unavailable)" because subagents cannot request interactive permissions

Instead: When using subagents for parallel work: (1) Have subagents do read-only tasks (research, exploration, planning), (2) Have the orchestrating agent do all file writes based on subagent findings, OR (3) Use worktrees but do the actual implementation work yourself after subagents gather context

structured.avoid: Spawned background subagents to write code in worktrees, but they failed with "Permission to use Write has been auto-denied (prompts unavailable)" because subagents cannot request interactive permissions
structured.prefer: When using subagents for parallel work: (1) Have subagents do read-only tasks (research, exploration, planning), (2) Have the orchestrating agent do all file writes based on subagent findings, OR (3) Use worktrees but do the actual implementation work yourself after subagents gather context

content.canonical: Create git worktrees in .worktrees/ directory at repo root (e.g., 'git worktree add .worktrees/feature-name -b branch-name'). This directory is in .gitignore so it won't pollute git status, and subagents can access it since it's inside the repo.
content.expanded:
When working on this type of task, avoid: Created git worktrees as sibling directories (../floop-*) which subagents couldn't access due to sandbox restrictions.

Instead: Create git worktrees in .worktrees/ directory at repo root (e.g., 'git worktree add .worktrees/feature-name -b branch-name'). This directory is in .gitignore so it won't pollute git status, and subagents can access it since it's inside the repo.

structured.prefer: Create git worktrees in .worktrees/ directory at repo root (e.g., 'git worktree add .worktrees/feature-name -b branch-name'). This directory is in .gitignore so it won't pollute git status, and subagents can access it since it's inside the repo.

content.canonical: Never destructively test commands on directories containing valuable data. Test with --json first, or test in temp directories. Global ~/.floop contains cross-project learnings that must be preserved.

Instead: Never destructively test commands on directories containing valuable data. Test with --json first, or test in temp directories. Global ~/.floop contains cross-project learnings that must be preserved.
